metadata.case_name: Assistant Custodian of Evacuee Property & Ors. v. Official Receiver

facts.text: Daulat Ram Surana, an Indian citizen, carried on business as a jeweller in Delhi under the name Sardar Singh Daulat Ram and had a Muslim mistress.
Daulat Ram Surana migrated to Pakistan in the first week of February 1950 (February 7 or 8, 1950) by reason of his affection for his Muslim mistress.
Before migrating, Daulat Ram Surana, involved in financial difficulties, transferred his 1/2 share in ancestral house in Baidwara Street, Delhi for Rs. 26,000.
On March 14, 1950, Nanak Chand and others filed a petition of insolvency against the firm of Daulat Ram and Daulat Ram himself.
On June 17, 1950, the firm and Daulat Ram were adjudicated insolvents and the Official Receiver (respondent) was appointed receiver of the estate.
In August 1951, Official Receiver wanted to sell items of insolvents' property, with sale fixed for August 18, 1951.

On August 16, 1951 (two days prior to sale), Assistant Custodian issued notice under S.7(1) of the Act to Daulat Ram and interested persons to show cause why he should not be declared evacuee under S.2(d)(i).
Official Receiver appeared before Assistant Custodian, raised objections; objections overruled.
On February 15, 1954, Assistant Custodian declared Daulat Ram's property as evacuee property.
Official Receiver appealed to Authorised Deputy Custodian; appeal dismissed.
Official Receiver filed revision before Custodian General; revision dismissed.
Official Receiver filed writ petition (Civil Writ No. 200-D of 1955) in Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi against Dy. Custodian, Authorised Dy. Custodian, and Assistant Custodian (appellants).
Punjab High Court (Bishan Narain J.) referred to Division Bench due to importance.
On April 18, 1960, Division Bench of Punjab High Court upheld respondent's plea, quashed orders declaring property as evacuee property vesting in Custodian.
High Court granted certificate; appellants appealed to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: What is the relevant date by reference to which the character of the property has to be determined in issuing a notification of evacuee property under section 7(1) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950?

petitioner_arguments.text: Vesting of evacuee property in Custodian under S.8(1)(a) takes effect from date of migration to Pakistan (Feb 7/8, 1950), earlier than insolvency petition date (March 14, 1950) to which adjudication relates back under S.28(7) Provincial Insolvency Act; thus declaration under S.7(1) prevails.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 Ss.7(1), 8(1)(a); Provincial Insolvency Act S.28(7)

petitioner_arguments.text: S.4(1) of the Act provides that its provisions prevail over any inconsistent law, including Provincial Insolvency Act Ss.27, 28(7).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 S.4(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Under S.7(1), Custodian need only consider if property was of the evacuee; literal grammatical construction leads to anomalous results frustrating Act's object.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 S.7(1); S.2(f), S.40

respondent_arguments.text: At time of notice (Aug 16, 1951) and declaration (Feb 15, 1954) under S.7(1), property had vested in Official Receiver from petition date (March 14, 1950) by relation back; Daulat Ram lost title, so property not evacuee property then.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Provincial Insolvency Act Ss.27, 28(7); Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 S.7(1), S.2(f)

respondent_arguments.text: S.7(1) requires Custodian's opinion that property 'is' evacuee property at time of forming opinion/declaration.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 S.7(1)

court_reasoning.text: S.8(1)(a) deems vesting from migration date only after valid declaration under S.7(1); S.7(1) cannot be construed using S.8(1). S.7(1) requires property to be evacuee property (property of evacuee) as at relevant time for declaration, not necessarily owned by evacuee at declaration date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Literal construction based on grammar alone leads to anomalous results frustrating Act's object to prevent evacuees converting property to cash; liberal construction considers if property was evacuee's.

court_reasoning.text: No inconsistency between Act and Provincial Insolvency Act; S.4(1) not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Insolvency vesting from petition date not overridden.

court_reasoning.text: Ebrahim Aboobaker case distinguished: applies to death pending proceedings, not to insolvency vesting; evacuee alive during enquiry here.

Act's scheme (S.40, S.7(1A), S.7(2)) covers pre-migration transfers, pending proceedings transfers, death pending proceedings; cannot intend to allow post-migration pre-proceedings transfers to defeat Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature would have explicitly exempted insolvency if intended.

holdings.text: For declaration under S.7(1), relevant date is whether property was evacuee property (i.e., of the evacuee), not requiring ownership at declaration date; vesting under S.8(1) then retrospective to migration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobaker and Anr. v. Tek Chand Dolwani
precedents_cited.relevance: Held proceedings under S.7(1) terminate on death of alleged evacuee as enquiry impossible; distinguished as evacuee alive here and no enquiry infirmity.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (No. 31 of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Core provisions for declaring and vesting evacuee property; S.7(1) construed to allow declaration if property was evacuee's; retrospective vesting under S.8(1); overrides inconsistent laws per S.4(1); scheme prevents evasion via transfers.

statutes_cited.name: Provincial Insolvency Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of insolvent's property in Official Receiver from petition date; not inconsistent with Evacuee Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; Punjab High Court order set aside; writ petition filed by Official Receiver dismissed. Custodian's declaration of Daulat Ram's property as evacuee property upheld.
outcome.relief_granted: None to respondent; custodians' orders restored.

key_quotes.text: What is the relevant date by reference to which the character of the property has to be determined in issuing a notification of evacuee property under section 7(1) of the Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950?
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the construction of s. 7(1) presents a problem which can be resolved not merely by the adoption of the mechanical rule of construction based on grammar, but by a liberal construction which takes into account the bearing and purport of the relevant words used in s. 7(1), considered in the light of the other relevant provisions of the Act and the principal object of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains approach to statutory interpretation rejecting strict grammar for purposive construction.

key_quotes.text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the view taken by the High Court does not correctly represent the true scope and effect of the provisions contained in S.7(1) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects High Court's view, allowing appeal.
